title: Road to Rio rougher for Canadian men's soccer after loss to U.S.
text:
Report an error 
A slow start doomed Canada’s under-23 men’s national team to an opening loss to the United States at CONCACAF’s men’s Olympic qualifying tournament in Kansas City, Kan., Thursday night. 
Jordan Morris opened the scoring less than a minute in before doubling the Americans’ advantage midway through the second half en route to a comfortable 3-1 win at Sporting Park. 
The loss sends Canada to the bottom of Group A after Panama and Cuba drew 1-1 prior to Thursday night’s fixture. 
The Canadians were attempting to repeat their feat from three years ago when they upset the Americans 2-0 in attempting to qualify for London 2012. 
This time, though, the U.S. scored early and never looked back. 
Left unmarked seconds after kickoff, Morris took advantage of a disorganized Canadian defence and connected on a header that beat Maxime Crepeau metres from goal. 
Morris doubled the U.S. advantage in the 73rd minute when he muscled off Canadian defender Luca Gasparotto at the top of the area before walking in on and scoring past Crepeau. 
Canada found a way back into the match 10 minutes from full-time when Michael Petrasso rose to meet a Chris Mannella corner, heading it down past American ’keeper Zack Steffen to cut the lead in half. 
But Les Rouges couldn’t find an equalizer. 
The Americans were awarded a late penalty after Jeremy Gagnon-Lapare brought down Jerome Kieseweeter inside the penalty area in stoppage time. 
Luis Gil converted from the spot to restore the two-goal advantage. 
Canada next plays Panama on Saturday in Group A action at Sporting Park before wrapping round-robin play against Cuba next Tuesday in Denver. 
The first-place and second-place finishers in Group A will cross over and meet the top two finishers in Group B in the tournament’s semi­final round. 
The winner of each semi­final automatically will qualify for next summer’s Rio Olympics, with the third-place finisher at the event meeting Colombia in a playoff for the final spot at the 2016 Games. Sponsored Links
